cards.back: The emission of electrons from a metal surface when light shines on it. Supports particle nature of light.
cards.subject: Physics - Modern Physics

cards.back: The concept that light and matter exhibit both wave-like and particle-like properties.
cards.subject: Physics - Modern Physics

cards.back: The branch of physics that describes the behavior of matter and energy at atomic and subatomic scales.
cards.subject: Physics - Modern Physics

cards.back: Einstein's theory that space and time are interconnected, and that the speed of light is constant for all observers.
cards.subject: Physics - Modern Physics

cards.back: The splitting of a heavy nucleus into smaller nuclei, releasing energy. Used in nuclear power plants.
cards.subject: Physics - Modern Physics

cards.back: The combining of light nuclei to form heavier nuclei, releasing energy. Powers the Sun and stars.
cards.subject: Physics - Modern Physics

cards.back: The spontaneous emission of radiation from unstable atomic nuclei. Types: alpha, beta, gamma decay.
cards.subject: Physics - Modern Physics

cards.back: The time required for half of a radioactive substance to decay. Each isotope has a unique half-life.
cards.subject: Physics - Modern Physics

cards.back: Einstein's famous equation E = mcÂ², showing that mass and energy are interchangeable.
cards.subject: Physics - Modern Physics

cards.back: Hypothetical matter that doesn't emit light but exerts gravitational force. Comprises most of the universe's mass.
cards.subject: Physics - Modern Physics
